title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: article describes standard dictionary human resource management information system (HRMIS) data, organized three main modules: Organization, Worker, Contract. modules designed organize standardize information public sector personnel across different countries administrative levels.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Organization module captures information public sector institutions, including ministries, departments, agencies.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Organization Type: Indicates hierarchical level institution within government structure. Ideally, support parent-child relationships, though data may rare practice. Administration Level: Refers geographic/administrative level government (e.g., national, state/provincial, local). Reference Date: Critical tracking organizational changes, mergers, renaming time.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Worker module contains demographic employment information individual public sector employees.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Education Categories: Multiple classification systems provided allow cross-country comparisons mapping international standards. Geographic Information: workers linked organizations, separate geographic fields allow tracking mobility remote work arrangements. Privacy Considerations: module contains sensitive personal information handled according applicable data protection regulations.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Contract module captures details employment contracts, compensation, job characteristics.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Compensation Fields: Multiple salary measures allow analysis gross--net ratios, taxation effects, allowances. Occupation Coding: native standardized (ISCO) classifications enable within-country detail cross-country comparability. Contract Duration: combination contract_type, start_date, end_date provides comprehensive information employment stability temporary arrangements.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: three modules related follows: One organization can many workers One organization can many contracts One worker can multiple contracts (time concurrent)
code: Organization (1) ←→ (N) Worker Organization (1) ←→ (N) Contract Worker (1) ←→ (N) Contract

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Temporal Consistency: Ensure ref_date fields properly maintained across modules Geographic Consistency: Country administration codes consistent across modules Unique Identifiers: ID fields globally unique persistent Missing Data: Document conventions handling missing unavailable data Historical Records: Consider versioning strategy tracking changes time

what: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: function calculates year--year growth rate specified numeric column data frame tibble. automatically completes missing time periods based range date column, ensuring continuous sequences computing growth. Growth computed consecutive years current previous values available. year missing sequence, growth next available year set `NA`.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: data data frame tibble containing variables interest. col numeric column compute growth (unquoted). date_col date year column used order complete data (unquoted).

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: tibble containing original columns plus new column holds computed year--year growth rates.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: function uses `tidyr::complete()` fill missing time periods `min(date_col)` `max(date_col)`, `dplyr::mutate()` compute growth : $$growth_t = \frac{x_t}{x_{t-1}} - 1$$ However, growth computed difference consecutive periods equals 1 (.e., consecutive years). time gap greater one year, growth value set `NA`.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
code: # Example data df <- tibble::tibble(   year = c(2020, 2021, 2023),   gdp = c(100, 110, 130) )  # Compute year-over-year growth compute_change(df, gdp, year) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>    year   gdp gdp_growth #>   <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1  2020   100     NA     #> 2  2021   110      0.100 #> 3  2022    NA     NA     #> 4  2023   130     NA

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
text: - Missing years sequence added automatically. - Missing values `col` result `NA` corresponding growth rate. - first observation (row lag missing) `NA`. - function can accept unquoted column names strings. - compute growth rates group (e.g., country), subset loop group calling function.

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
code: library(data.table)  dt <- data.table(   year = c(2020, 2021, 2023),   gdp = c(100, 110, 130) )   # Using strings compute_fastchange(dt, "gdp", "year") #> Key: <year> #>     year   gdp gdp_growth #>    <int> <num>      <num> #> 1:  2020   100         NA #> 2:  2021   110        0.1 #> 3:  2022    NA         NA #> 4:  2023   130         NA

what: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: `compute_fastshare()` summarizes selected numeric columns specified groups, merges result macroeconomic indicators, computes ratios summarized variables per macro variable, returns either long wide-format data.table.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
code: compute_fastshare(   data,   macro_data = as.data.table(macro_indicators),   macro_cols,   cols,   groups = c("country_code", "year"),   fns,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: data data.frame data.table containing raw data summarize. macro_data data.frame data.table containing macro-level indicators. Must share least one common grouping variable `data`. Default `macro_indicators`. macro_cols character vector column names `macro_data` use denominators ratio calculations. cols character vector column names `data` summarize. groups character vector column names `data` group . Typically includes country date/year variables. Default `c("country_code", "year")`. fns character vector summary functions apply `cols`. Examples: `"sum"`, `"mean"`, `"median"`. output Either `"long"` `"wide"` (default `"long"`). - `"long"` returns tidy table columns: group variables, `macro_var`, `summary_var`, `indicator`, `value`. - `"wide"` returns table one column per indicator original macro/summary values.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: `data.table` containing: - `"long"` format: group variables, `macro_var`, `macro_value`, `summary_var`, `summary_value`, `indicator`, `value`. - `"wide"` format: group variables, one column per indicator (`summary_var` per `macro_var`), original macro summary values.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: function works follows: 1. Summarizes `cols` `groups` using functions `fns`. 2. Automatically detects common join variables `summary_dt` `macro_data`. 3. Merges summarized data macro indicators. 4. Computes ratio indicators (`summary_value / macro_value`) combinations summarized columns macro columns. 5. Optionally reshapes result wide format one column per indicator.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  dt <- contract_harmonized |> mutate(year = year(org_date)) |> as.data.table()   compute_fastshare(   data = dt,   macro_cols = c("gdp_lcu", "pexpenditure_lcu"),   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu", "base_salary_lcu"),   fns = c("sum", "mean"),   output = "long",   groups = c("country_code", "year") )  ## produce results in wide format compute_fastshare(   data = dt,   macro_cols = c("gdp_lcu", "pexpenditure_lcu"),   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu", "base_salary_lcu"),   fns = c("sum", "mean"),   output = "wide",   groups = c("country_code", "year") ) } # }

what: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: Computes summary statistics specified numeric columns data frame data.table, optionally grouped one categorical variables. function supports predefined summary functions (e.g., mean, sum) user-specified formulas. returns results either long wide format, can optionally convert output tibble.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
code: compute_fastsummary(   data,   cols,   fns = NULL,   groups,   output = c("long", "wide"),   tbl = FALSE )

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: data data.table data.frame containing data summarize. cols character vector specifying names numeric columns summarize. fns Optional. character vector list formulas specifying summary functions apply. NULL, default functions defined define_fns() used. - character vector, function names must match defaults (e.g., "mean", "sum"). - list, can contain formulas mix character names formulas. groups character vector specifying one grouping variables. output character string specifying output format. Must one : - "long": produces tall table indicator column value column. - "wide": produces wide table one column per statistic. tbl Logical. TRUE, converts resulting data.table tibble.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: data.table (tibble tbl = TRUE) containing summary statistics group, either long wide format.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: function first matches output argument, loads default summary functions define_fns(), determines functions apply based user input. uses efficient data.table operations grouped computation, optionally reshapes output long format data.table::melt().

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage: compute_fastsummary( data = contract_harmonized |> as.data.table(), cols = c("base_salary_lcu", "gross_salary_lcu"), fns = c("mean", "sum"), groups = c("occupation_isconame", "year"), output = "long" ) } # }

what: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: function generates suite standardized analytical tables HRMIS (Human Resource Management Information System) reports. combines contract-level, worker-level, organizational data compute wage bill summaries, employment shares, decompositions, profiles occupation, pay grade, organization, education, seniority.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: contract_dt `data.table` containing individual employment contracts variables `worker_id`, `ref_date`, wage variables (`gross_salary_lcu`, `net_salary_lcu`, `base_salary_lcu`), job attributes. worker_dt `data.table` containing worker-level panel data, including `worker_id`, `ref_date`, demographic employment information. org_dt `data.table` containing organizational information (e.g., institution identifiers, types, sectors).

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: named list `data.table` objects containing: wagebill_shares Wage bill components shares macro indicators. publicemployment_share Public employment share total employment. wagebill_occupisco Wage bill decomposition ISCO occupation group. wagebill_occupnative Wage bill decomposition native occupational titles. wagebill_orgdecomp Wage bill decomposition organization. wagebill_allowshare_paygrade Allowance rate pay grade. wagebill_allowshare_seniority Allowance rate seniority. workerevent Worker-level hiring, firing, retirement events time. employment_decomp Employment decomposition occupation ISCO group. org_decomp Employment decomposition organization. education_profile Distribution public sector workers education, gender, occupation. mobilityprofile Distribution public sector workers pay grade, seniority, gender, occupation.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: function integrates contract, worker, organizational datasets compute standardized HRMIS statistical report. relies supporting helper functions : convert_constant_ppp(), compute_fastshare(), compute_fastsummary(), detect_worker_event(), detect_retirement(). sub-table output list can used directly dashboards, reports, analytical aggregation.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats

what: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: function calculates ratio (share) summarized microdata indicators macro-level indicators (e.g., GDP, total population, etc.). automatically detects common join keys micro-level summary macro-level data, merges , computes ratios possible combinations summarized macro variables.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
code: compute_share(   data,   macro_data = macro_indicators,   macro_cols,   cols,   groups,   fns,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: data data frame containing microdata summarized. macro_data data frame containing macro-level indicators. Defaults macro_indicators available environment. macro_cols character vector specifying names macro indicator columns macro_data use share computation. cols named list passed compute_summary(), specifying variables summarize (e.g. list(vars = "varname")). groups character vector specifying grouping variables common datasets. Defaults c("country_code", "ref_date"). fns list summary functions passed compute_summary(), typically defined formulas (e.g. list(mean = ~mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))). output Character string indicating desired output format: "long" (default) tidy data frame one row per share, "wide" data frame one column per computed indicator.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: data frame containing computed ratios (shares). output = "long", columns include: Grouping variables (e.g., country_code, ref_date) macro_var, macro_value summary_var, summary_value indicator – constructed name ratio value – computed share output = "wide", ratio indicator returned separate column.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: function proceeds five steps: Summarizes microdata using compute_summary(). Automatically detects join keys shared summary macro data. Merges summarized macro data join keys. Computes ratio summarized indicator macro indicator. Formats output either long wide form, depending output argument. output always includes computed shares (e.g. employment_per_GDP), well underlying macro summary values used compute .

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage compute_share(data = contract_harmonized,               macro_cols = c("gdp_lcu", "prevenue_lcu"),               cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu"),               fns = c("mean", "sum"),               output = "wide") } # }

what: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: flexible wrapper around `dplyr::summarise()` `dplyr::across()` computes one summary statistics set numeric variables, optionally grouped one categorical variables. Users can choose built-summary functions defined [define_fns()] supply .

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
code: compute_summary(   data,   cols,   fns = NULL,   groups = NULL,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: data data frame tibble containing variables summarize. cols character vector variable names summarize, list element `vars` (e.g., `list(vars = c("var1", "var2"))`). fns Optional. specification summary functions apply: - `NULL` (default): applies default functions returned [define_fns()]. - **character vector** function names (e.g., `c("mean", "sd")`)   referring defaults [define_fns()]. - **list** formulas (e.g., `list(mean = ~mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))`)   mix character names formulas. groups character vector grouping variables used aggregation. output Character, either `"long"` `"wide"`. `"long"`, reshapes results tidy format columns `indicator` `value`. Defaults `"long"`.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: tibble containing grouped summary statistics. - `output = "wide"`, statistic appears separate column. - `output = "long"`, data tidy (long) format one row per   group-variable-statistic combination.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: function simplifies grouped summaries handling: - Flexible function definitions (`fns`) using formula notation `~expr(.x)`. - Integration user-defined functions via [define_fns()]. - Optional long/wide reshaping tidy analysis workflows.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: default functions defined [define_fns()] typically include: `sum`, `mean`, `median`, `cv`, `cp_ratio`. can customized extended modifying `define_fns()`.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
code: df <- tibble::tibble(   country = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 5),   year = rep(2020:2021, times = 5),   income = runif(10, 1000, 2000),   expenditure = runif(10, 500, 1500) )   # Default summaries by country and year compute_summary(data = df,                 cols = c("income", "expenditure"),                 groups = c("country", "year"),                 fns = "mean") #> # A tibble: 8 × 4 #>   country  year indicator        value #>   <chr>   <int> <chr>            <dbl> #> 1 A        2020 income_mean      1589. #> 2 A        2020 expenditure_mean  995. #> 3 A        2021 income_mean      1469. #> 4 A        2021 expenditure_mean 1034. #> 5 B        2020 income_mean      1364. #> 6 B        2020 expenditure_mean  930. #> 7 B        2021 income_mean      1481. #> 8 B        2021 expenditure_mean 1055.   # Select specific functions  compute_summary(data = df,                 cols = c("income"),                 groups = c("country"),                 fns = c("mean", "sd"),                 output = "wide") #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   country income_mean income_sd #>   <chr>         <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 A             1541.      397. #> 2 B             1434.      295.   # Custom function  compute_summary(df,                 cols = "income",                 groups = "country",                 fns = list("cv",                            q90 = ~quantile(.x, 0.9, na.rm = TRUE))) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   country indicator     value #>   <chr>   <chr>         <dbl> #> 1 A       income_cv     0.258 #> 2 A       income_q90 1885.    #> 3 B       income_cv     0.206 #> 4 B       income_q90 1693.

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
text: contract_harmonized dataset contains 50,000 synthetic contract-level observations consistent harmonization dictionary "Contract" module. record represents employment contract worker within organization, capturing key information compensation, contract characteristics, administrative geography. records pertain Zambia (ISO3: ZMB).

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
text: data frame 50,000 rows 21 variables: contract_id Character. Unique identifier contract (e.g., "C000001"). worker_id Character. Identifier worker associated contract (e.g., "W03583"). org_id Character. Employer organization associated contract (e.g., "ORG0194"). ref_date Date. Date contract record entry YYYY-MM-DD format. base_salary_lcu Numeric. Basic pay allowances deductions. gross_salary_lcu Numeric. Total compensation taxes deductions. net_salary_lcu Numeric. Take-home pay taxes deductions. contract_type Character. Type employment contract — one "Short-term", "Open-term", "Permanent". occupation_native Character. Worker’s occupation title native language (e.g., "Comptable", "Analyste"). occupation_english Character. Worker’s occupation title English (e.g., "Accountant", "Engineer"). occupation_isconame Character. Occupation name mapped ISCO-08 classification (e.g., "Technicians"). occupation_iscocode Character. ISCO-08 occupation code (e.g., "2411", "2141", "8322"). start_date Date. Start date employment contract (YYYY-MM-DD). end_date Date. End date employment contract, applicable (YYYY-MM-DD). whours Numeric. Total weekly monthly working hours per contract. paygrade Character. Pay grade salary scale classification (e.g., "G7", "P1"). seniority Numeric. Number years service tenure within organization. country_code Character. ISO 3-letter country code ("ZMB"). country_name Character. Country name ("Zambia"). adm1_name Character. Subnational administrative division name (e.g., "Lusaka Province"). adm1_code Character. Code corresponding administrative division (e.g., "ZMB02").

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
text: Synthetic data generated using Python demonstration purposes.

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized

what: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: Convert nominal wages (LCU survey-year prices) real wages expressed 2021 PPP international dollars using: $$Real_{h}^{PPP} = (CPI_t / CPI_{2021}) * (Nominal_{h,t} / PPP_{2021})$$

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: data Data frame columns (country_code, year, wage). cols Column name convert constant PPP international 2021 dollars. macro_indicators Macroeconomic indicators, can lazy loaded.

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: `data_out` augmented columns converted international 2021 dollars.

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: Assumes - `data` columns: country_code, year, wage - `cpi` columns: country_code, year, cpi - `ppp` columns: country_code, ppp  (ppp = LCU per 2021 Intl$)

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
code: library(tibble) hh <- tibble(   country_code = c("A","A"),   year = c("2010", "2021"),   wage = c(20000, 25000) )  macro_indicators <- tibble(   country_code = "A", year = "2010", "2021",   cpi = c(85, 100), ppp = c(1.5, 3.5) )  convert_constant_ppp(hh, wage, macro_indicators) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>   country_code year   wage `"2021"`   cpi   ppp #>   <chr>        <chr> <dbl> <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 A            2010     NA 2021        85   1.5 #> 2 A            2010     NA 2021       100   3.5 #> 3 A            2021     NA NA          NA  NA

title: Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
text: Converts dataset class another reference dataset. useful ensuring consistent output formats performing operations temporarily convert data structures (e.g., `data.table`, `data.frame`, `tibble`).

title: Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
text: data dataset converted. Typically `data.table` `data.frame`. data_original original dataset whose class matched.

title: Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
text: input data converted class data_original.

title: Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
text: function checks class data_original following order: tibble (`tbl_df`), data converted using     tibble::as_tibble(). base data frame data.table, data converted     using .data.frame(). Otherwise, data returned unchanged (e.g., data.table input).

title: Convert Data to Match Original Class — convert_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ df <- data.frame(x = 1:3) dt <- data.table::as.data.table(df)  # Convert dt back to data.frame to match df convert_data(dt, df)  # Convert to tibble if original was tibble convert_data(dt, tibble::as_tibble(df)) } # }

text: x numeric vector values (e.g., wages salaries). upper Numeric; upper percentile compute (default `0.9` 90th percentile). lower Numeric; lower percentile compute (default `0.1` 10th percentile). na.rm Logical; `TRUE`, missing values (`NA`) removed computation. Defaults `TRUE`.

title: Compute a Compression Ratio Between Two Percentiles — cp_ratio
text: numeric value representing ratio specified upper lower percentile values. Returns `NA_real_` computation possible (e.g., due missing data zero denominator).

what: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
text: function deduplicates values within groups defined combination identifier date columns. provides three strategies: "mode": returns frequent (modal) value group. "first": returns first value group, even NA. "first_nonmissing": returns first non-missing value group.

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
code: dedup_values(   data,   id_col,   date_col,   value_col,   method = c("mode", "first", "first_nonmissing") )

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
text: data data frame tibble containing data deduplicate. id_col Column name identifying grouping unit (e.g., individual, firm). date_col Column name identifying date time grouping variable. value_col Column name containing values deduplicate. method string specifying deduplication method. Must one "mode", "first", "first_nonmissing".

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
text: tibble one row per unique combination id_col date_col, containing deduplicated value_col.

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
text: method = "mode", ties broken arbitrarily selecting first encountered maximum. Missing values ignored computing mode.

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:data.table’: #>  #>     between, first, last #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  df <- tibble(   id = c(1,1,1, 2,2,2, 3,3,3),   date = c("2020-01","2020-01","2020-01",            "2020-02","2020-02","2020-02",            "2021-01","2021-01","2021-01"),   gender = c("M","M","F", NA,"F","M", "M","F",NA) )  dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "mode") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 F      #> 3     3 2021-01 F      dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "first") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 NA     #> 3     3 2021-01 M      dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "first_nonmissing") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 F      #> 3     3 2021-01 M

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: Creates returns named list default summary functions used throughout analytics framework (e.g., [compute_summary()]). function defined purrr-style formula (`~`) operates vector `.x` returns scalar summary statistic. returned list can supplied directly summarization pipeline extended users custom functions.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: list includes following summary functions: sum Sum values, ignoring `NA`s. mean Arithmetic mean. median Median value. cv Coefficient variation (requires `cv()` helper). cp_ratio Custom "cp ratio" statistic (requires `cp_ratio()` helper). var Sample variance. iqr Interquartile range, computed `diff(range(.x))`. min Minimum value. max Maximum value. count Number observations. count_unique Number distinct (unique) values. prop_na Proportion missing (`NA`) values. prop_zero Proportion zero values among non-missing data. p25 25th percentile (first quartile). p75 75th percentile (third quartile). p90 90th percentile. sd Standard deviation.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: named list formula functions suitable use `dplyr::across()`, element name function label value one-sided formula computes summary.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: returned list contains commonly used descriptive statistics numeric vectors, including measures central tendency, dispersion, distribution, data quality (e.g., share missing zero values). Users can extend override defaults appending named formulas passing [compute_summary()].

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
code: # Load the default function set fns <- define_fns()  # Inspect available summaries names(fns) #>  [1] "sum"          "mean"         "median"       "cv"           "cp_ratio"     #>  [6] "var"          "iqr"          "min"          "max"          "count"        #> [11] "prop"         "dtprop"       "count_unique" "prop_na"      "prop_zero"    #> [16] "p25"          "p75"          "p90"          "sd"            # Example usage with compute_summary() compute_summary(   data = contract_harmonized,   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu"),   groups = c("country_code"),   fns = c("mean", "sd", "cv") ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   country_code indicator                value #>   <chr>        <chr>                    <dbl> #> 1 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_mean 5321.    #> 2 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_sd    880.    #> 3 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_cv      0.165 #> 4 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_mean   4312.    #> 5 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_sd      764.    #> 6 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_cv        0.177

                 Please refer to: https://mtimodelling.worldbank.org/resources/MTI_Macro_Econometric_Model.pdf #> 44 The Macro Poverty Outlook (MPO) analyzes macroeconomic and poverty developments in 147 developing countries. The report is released twice annually for the Spring and Annual Meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The MPO consists of individual country notes that provide an overview of recent developments, forecasts of major macroeconomic variables and poverty during 2024-2026, and a discussion of critical challenges for economic growth, macroeconomic stability, and poverty reduction moving forward.\n\nFor further details, please refer to https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/macro-poverty-outlook #> title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: structured metadata dictionary describing variables harmonized across Human Resource Management Information System (HRMIS) modules: Organization, Worker, Contract. dictionary follows SDMX-style documentation standards specifies variable names, identifiers, data types (R), relationships, metadata fields used HRMIS data harmonization.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: tibble 48 rows 9 variables: Concept Name Variable concept name used HRMIS module. Concept ID Short machine-readable variable name used datasets. Description Detailed explanation variable concept. Data Type R data type assigned variable (e.g., character, numeric, Date). Representation (Code list / Format) Expected format, code list, data representation. Primary Key Indicates whether variable uniquely identifies record ("Yes" ""). Relationship Describes relational links modules variables. Module HRMIS module variable belongs : "Organization", "Worker", "Contract". Example Value Illustrative example value variable.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: dictionary integrates HRMIS modules single metadata table. designed use R-based harmonization workflows conforms SDMX Content-Oriented Guidelines (COG) defining concepts, code lists, roles.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: SDMX Technical Standards v3.0 — Data Structure Definition (DSD): https://sdmx.org/?page_id=5008 SDMX Content-Oriented Guidelines (COG): https://sdmx.org/?page_id=4345 Eurostat SDMX Metadata Reference Manual: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/metadata/reference-metadata-reporting-standards

what: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: function standardizes column names data frame using dictionary maps inconsistent time-varying column names standardized set column names.

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: data data frame whose columns need renamed. dictionary Either named character vector (names desired standardized column names values original column names), data frame two columns: `` (original column names) `` (standardized names).

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: data frame harmonized column names.

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
code: # Using a named character vector dict <- c("age" = "Q1_age", "gender" = "Q2_sex", "income" = "Q3_income") df <- data.frame(Q1_age = 25, Q2_sex = "M", Q3_income = 50000) harmonize_columns(df, dict) #>   age gender income #> 1  25      M  50000  # Using a data frame dictionary dict_df <- data.frame(   from = c("Q1_age", "Q2_sex", "Q3_income"),   to = c("age", "gender", "income") ) harmonize_columns(df, dict_df) #>   age gender income #> 1  25      M  50000

what: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: dataset containing structure International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO-08), published International Labour Organization (ILO).

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: data frame 436 rows 9 variables: isco_version Character. Version ISCO classification (e.g., `"ISCO-08"`). major Character. One-digit major group code. major_label Character. Title major group (e.g., `"Managers"`). sub_major Character. Two-digit sub-major group code. sub_major_label Character. Title sub-major group (e.g.,   `"Chief Executives, Senior Officials Legislators"`). minor Character. Three-digit minor group code. minor_label Character. Title minor group (e.g.,   `"Legislators Senior Officials"`). unit Character. Four-digit unit group code. description Character. Definition title occupation   unit group level (e.g., `"Legislators"`, `"Senior Government Officials"`).

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: International Labour Organization (ILO), https://www.ilo.org/public/english/bureau/stat/isco/

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: ISCO provides system classifying aggregating occupational information facilitate international comparisons harmonization occupational statistics. widely used labor statistics, survey design, policy analysis. ISCO-08 structured hierarchically: - Major groups (1 digit) – broad occupational categories - Sub-major groups (2 digits) – subdivisions major groups - Minor groups (3 digits) – subdivisions sub-major groups - Unit groups (4 digits) – detailed level, individual occupations unit group includes description outlining scope occupation according ILO’s ISCO-08 documentation.

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco

what: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: lightweight helper function applies list functions set variables, mimicking behavior `dplyr::summarise_at()`, designed use within `data.table` syntax. useful want compute several summary statistics (e.g., mean, sd) subset columns defined `.SD` `.SDcols`.

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: var vector, list, data frame-like object (e.g., `.SD` inside `data.table` call) containing variables functions applied. funs character vector function names (e.g., `"mean"`, `"sd"`, `"sum"`) list function objects applied element `var`. ... Additional arguments passed function call (e.g., `na.rm = TRUE`).

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: named list element corresponds combination variable   function (e.g., `Sepal.Length_mean`, `Sepal.Length_sd`), suitable   use inside `data.table::lapply()`.

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
code: library(data.table) iris_dt <- as.data.table(iris)  # Compute mean and sd for Sepal variables by Species iris_dt[, lapply_at(.SD, c("mean", "sd"), na.rm = TRUE),         .SDcols = patterns("^Sepal"),         by = Species] #>       Species Sepal.Length_mean Sepal.Length_sd Sepal.Width_mean Sepal.Width_sd #>        <fctr>             <num>           <num>            <num>          <num> #> 1:     setosa             5.006       0.3524897            3.428      0.3790644 #> 2: versicolor             5.936       0.5161711            2.770      0.3137983 #> 3:  virginica             6.588       0.6358796            2.974      0.3224966

what: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: dataset contains selection macroeconomic labor market indicators multiple countries years. data primarily sourced World Bank World Development Indicators (WDI) via Data360 API. variables renamed convenience, original WDI variable codes provided reference.

title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: tibble 11652 rows 14 variables: country_code ISO3 country code (originally Data360 API). year Year observation (character, originally Data360 API). gdp_lcu Gross Domestic Product (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_NY_GDP_MKTP_CN. pexpenditure_lcu Total government expenditure (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_XPN_TOTL_CN. prevenue_lcu Total government revenue (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_REV_XGRT_CN. taxrevenue_lcu Total government tax revenue (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_TAX_TOTL_CN. emp_pop_rate Employment--population ratio (percent). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_EMP_TOTL_SP_NE_ZS. labor_force_total Labor force, total. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_TLF_TOTL_IN. labor_force_advanced_edu Labor force advanced education (percentage total working-age population advanced education). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_TLF_ADVN_ZS. tot_pop Total population. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SP_POP_TOTL. government_expenditure_gdp General government final consumption expenditure (percentage GDP). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_NE_CON_GOVT_ZS. salaried_rate Share employed people salaried (percent). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_EMP_WORK_ZS. cpi Consumer Price Index, total. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_FP_CPI_TOTL. ppp Purchasing Power Parity (local currency units per international USD). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_PA_NUS_PRVT_PP. fiscal_balance Overall Fiscal Balance, USD, percentage GDP. emp_pop population employed .e. `emp_pop_rate` * `tot_pop`. salaried_pop population salaried workers .e. `salaried_rate` * `emp_pop`.

what: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: function reshapes Data360-style dataset long wide format. spreads indicator values (`OBS_VALUE`) across multiple columns based indicator variable (`INDICATOR`), keeping reference area time period identifiers. resulting dataset renamed cleaned snake_case variable names.

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: data data frame tibble containing variables: - `REF_AREA`: Country region code - `TIME_PERIOD`: Year time reference - `INDICATOR`: Indicator code name - `OBS_VALUE`: Observation value indicator

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: tibble wide format columns:   - `country_code`: country region code (`REF_AREA`)   - `year`: year time period (`TIME_PERIOD`)   - One column per unique `INDICATOR`, containing corresponding values `OBS_VALUE`

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: function particularly useful preparing Data360 similar datasets analysis, multiple indicators recorded country year. output dataset cleaned using `janitor::clean_names()` ensure consistent naming.

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr)  data_long <- tibble(   REF_AREA = c("USA", "USA", "CAN", "CAN"),   TIME_PERIOD = c(2020, 2020, 2020, 2020),   INDICATOR = c("GDP", "POP", "GDP", "POP"),   OBS_VALUE = c(21000, 330, 1800, 38) )  data_wide <- pivot_data360(data_long) print(data_wide) #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   country_code  year   gdp   pop #>   <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 USA           2020 21000   330 #> 2 CAN           2020  1800    38

title: Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators — wwbi
text: Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators (WWBI) database unique cross-national dataset public sector employment wages aims fill information gap, thereby helping researchers, development practitioners, policymakers gain better understanding personnel dimensions state capability, footprint public sector within overall labor market, fiscal implications public sector wage bill. dataset derived administrative data household surveys, thereby complementing existing, expert perception-based approaches.
